acknowledged by a notary public and in a form approved by the responsible planning department 2 a certification by the director or designee of the responsible planning department indicating that it has been submitted to and approved by such responsible planning department pursuant to these regulations in a form approved by the responsible planning department b the responsible planning department shall file the boundary line adjustment with the appropriate register of deeds when all requirements of this been met if such requirements have not been met within one 1 year of the approval of the boundary line adjustment the approval shall have been deemed to have been withdrawn and the boundary line adjustment survey shall not be filed without a reapproval by the responsible planning department article viii public improvements 8101 all public improvements necessary to serve a subdivision such as but not limited to streets sidewalks storm sewers utilities drainage improvements etc shall be constructed and financed pursuant to the policies rules regulations and laws of the responsible governing body and also pursuant to these regulations where applicable 8102 the responsible governing body may include part or all of any subdivision within a benefit district to finance the construction of public improvements necessary to serve such subdivision whether or not such improvements are located within or without such subdivision the responsible governing body shall comply with all applicable rules regulations ordinances and statutes in the creation of such benefit district 8103 the muapb may make written recommendations to the responsible governing body concerning any factor the board deems relevant related to the construction andor financing of public improvements necessary to serve an approved subdivision such recommendations shall not be binding upon the governing body and shall not affect the approval of the plat in addition to such recommendations the muapb may deny approval of a plat or condition such approval based upon a finding that necessary public facilities or services will not be available to the platted area within a reasonable time pursuant to of these regulations viii1 article ix reserved ix1 article x subdivision layout standards part 1 general standards 10101 scope all subdivision plats shall be prepared in conformity with the standards set forth herein the layout and location of areas on plats proposed to be dedicated to the public for uses such as streets storm and sanitary sewerage systems water supply systems and other utilities shall also be consistent with the standards for such public improvements that may be adopted by the applicable governing body or the applicable engineering department 10102 policy and plan coordination all subdivision plats shall conform with the applicable adopted comprehensive plans and policies of the city of manhattan or riley county 10103 access all lots located on a subdivision plat shall directly abut and be served directly by a public street or travel easement 10104 flood plain areas all subdivision plats shall conform to the requirements of the flood plain regulations of the manhattan zoning or the zoning regulations of riley county kansas whichever is applicable 10105 land subject to erosion on land subject to excessive soil movement that may result in erosion or deposition of soil the muapb in accordance with the city or county engineers recommendations may require necessary preventive measures as part of the preliminary or final plat approval all provisions of the environmental protection agencys national pollutant discharge elimination system npdes storm water regulations shall be followed 10106 subdivision name the proposed name of the subdivision shall not duplicate or too closely approximate in sound or spelling any existing subdivision in either riley county or pottawatomie county 10107 conformance to applicable laws and regulations in addition to the requirements established herein all subdivision plats where applicable shall comply with the following laws and regulations a the city or county zoning regulations respectively  b the riley county health departments regulations  c the regulations of the kansas state department of transportation if the subdivision or any lot contained therein abuts a state highway  x1 d the citycounty building and housing codes respectively  e the citycounty fire and life safety codes respectively  f the standards and regulations utilized by the citycounty engineer respectively  g where there is a discrepancy between minimum standards or dimensions noted herein and those contained in the above official regulations the more restrictive standard shall apply  and h any other applicable statutory provisions part 2 street standards 10201 introduction a it is the goal and the responsibility of these regulations to provide for a safe convenient adequate and comprehensively planned street system that provides for all forms of transportation including motor vehicles bicycles and pedestrians the system should coordinate and provide connections for bicycles and pedestrians that are an integral part of the overall transportation network the system should be logical and respect the natural features of the community the specific standards applicable to the system must address the specific needs of the users related to the functional classification of the particular street and bicycle and pedestrian connections to that system b street classification streets are classified according to their function as defined by these regulations streets shall generally consist of arterial collector and local streets c general requirements 1 the layout of streets on subdivision plats shall be consistent with the applicable standards adopted by the respective governing bodies within the city and the urban service area the city of manhattans design standards and specifications shall be the applicable standard within the urban area the specifications for streets construction and design subdivision regulations of riley county shall apply in addition such layout of streets shall where applicable be consistent with the comprehensive plan functional street classification map bicycle master plan manhattan linear park phase ii master plan and all other adopted plans of the applicable governing body 2 in order to promote connectivity to adjacent properties every plat shall provide multiple access points to the greatest extent possible streets in a proposed subdivision must connect where feasible to existing streets in x2 abutting platted subdivisions and streets must be continued to the boundaries of the tract being platted such that future abutting subdivisions may be connected unless the muapb finds that the minimum requirements are not reasonable due to the topography or other existing physical conditions of the site  or if the muapb finds that such minimum requirements are not necessary or desirable for coordination of the subdivisions layout with existing adjoining layouts or the most advantageous future layouts of adjoining tracts in making findings that the minimum requirements are not required the muapb shall consider the recommendations of the applicable fire department 10202 standards regarding topography and arrangement of streets a local streets shall be laid out to conform as much as possible to match the existing topography to permit efficient drainage and utility systems and to require the minimum number of streets for providing safe and efficient access to property streets shall not intersect with themselves through traffic on local residential streets should be discouraged if fourlegged intersections are utilized traffic calming measures may be recommended by the city or county engineer and approved by the muapb and made a condition of plat approval the use of threelegged intersections ts is encouraged when appropriate b any type of street layout pattern may be used that best fits the topography a curvilinear system grid system or modified grid system are acceptable alternatives culdesac use should be carefully considered in the planning of a subdivision to ensure that all forms of vehicular and pedestrian traffic demands and other safety issues such as fire access have been adequately addressed c in commercial or industrial developments the streets and other access ways shall be planned in connection with the grouping of buildings location of rail facilities and the provision of alleys truck loading and maneuvering areas walks and parking areas so as to minimize conflict of movement between the various types of traffic including pedestrian 10203 standards for bicycle and pedestrian access a bicycle and pedestrian access are an integral component of the overall transportation network planning for the effective provision for bicycle and pedestrian access begins with the subdivision process so as to ensure that safe convenient and adequate facilities are accommodated 1 bicycle lanes and routes x3 a at a minimum the layout of streets and other public ways on plats shall be adequate to accommodate bicycle lanes and routes wherever such lanes or routes are identified by the bicycle master plan b bicycle lanes or routes must reflect the overall planning of the area in which the subdivision is located bicycle lanes and routes shall connect with any anticipated existing or planned bicycle lane or route linear trail and street network 2 pedestrian access a sidewalks 1 at a minimum the layout of streets and other public ways on plats shall be adequate to accommodate sidewalks that comply with this b linear trail 1 linear trail extensions and other pedestrian connections when appropriate shall be provided in accordance with the manhattan linear park master plan phase ii implementation guidelines c pedestrian easements 1 pedestrian easements shall be provided according to c and h 10204 standards for street names a a street which is planned as a continuation of an existing street shall have the same name names of new streets shall not be so similar in sound andor spelling to existing streets names as to cause confusion or misunderstanding irrespective of a suffix b street names shall be subject to the review of the planning departments public works department fire department post office and police department street suffixes shall be used to provide for a uniform classification of street functions in the following manner 1 boulevard and parkway shall be reserved for major arterial streets 2 avenue and parkway shall be used in conjunction with arterial and collector streets x4 3 drive road terrace street and way shall be used in conjunction with local streets 4 lane circle and court shall be used in conjunction with culdesacs 5 place shall only be used in conjunction with travel easements c nothing contained herein shall be deemed to prevent limit or restrict the applicable governing body from renaming any street once the street has been dedicated to the public to any name said governing body deems appropriate 10205 standards for layout and dedication of temporary deadend streets and culdesacs a temporary deadend streets if the property adjacent to a proposed subdivision is undeveloped any street that comes to a temporary deadend and would be extended into a future subdivision on the adjacent property may be required to have a temporary t turnaround the provision of the t turnaround shall not affect street rightsofway and the t shall not extend out of the street or utility easement b culdesacs culdesacs may be allowed where continuous street connections are not necessary or where other options are not practical due to topographical constraints culdesacs shall provide adequate access to all abutting properties when culdesacs are used pedestrian and bicycle access culdesac to adjacent area shall be adequately accommodated the culdesac rightofway leading to the end of the turnaround shall be the minimum set out in the table 1 minimum rightofway widths feet the minimum diameter of the culdesac turnaround shall be onehundred 100 feet in diameter the maximum length of a culdesac shall be sixhundred 600 feet from the centerline of the intersecting street along the centerline of the culdesac to the center of the turnaround in those instances where the muapb approves a variation pursuant to allowing a culdesac greater than six hundred 600 feet in length the subdivider shall be required to provide a street consistent with the city of manhattans design standards and specifications or the specifications for streets construction and design subdivision regulations of riley county where applicable 10206 standards for travel easements a travel easements are similar to public streets in that they provide the public with x5 legal access to abutting private property travel easements differ from public streets in that the improvement located within the easement is owned constructed repaired and maintained by the owners of abutting or nearby properties b travel easements identified on any plat shall be deemed to grant an easement to the public for travel to the same extent as would be permitted over a public street c the following shall apply to travel easements 1 travel easements shall only be allowed in planned unit developments 2 travels easements shall not be permitted if the applicable governing body desires to accept dedication of such area as a public street 3 travel easements shall only be used to provide internal access to properties within a subdivision and shall not be permitted to provide access between subdivisions 4 improvements within a travel easement shall be designed constructed repaired and maintained pursuant to policies adopted by the applicable governing body 5 subdividers desiring to create a travel easement shall be required to file restrictive covenants or similar documents which legally bind abutting properties to construct repair and maintain the improvements pursuant to these regulations such covenants shall be in a form approved by the applicable governing body shall be enforceable by that governing body and shall not be permitted to be amended or removed without the consent of that governing body the applicable governing body may require that the enforcement of such covenants include the ability of the governing body to make such repairs or conduct such maintenance that the abutting properties fail to provide and to assess the costs of such to such abutting properties 10207 standards for access management a access management access management includes the control of the spacing location of driveways side streets and intersections effective access management is essential to achieving safe and efficient traffic operations on the major street system the amount of access should decrease as the functional classification of the street increases b driveway and street spacing driveways to abutting property should be x6 confined to local streets direct access to arterial and collector streets should be prohibited unless no reasonable alternative is available there are two primary aspects to driveway spacing one is the relationship of an intersecting side street or driveway relative to the intersection of arterial and collector streets the other aspect is the relationship between intersecting local streets or driveways along an arterial or collector street the following standards are hereby required 1along an arterial street with speeds equal to or greater than 50 mph no side street or driveway shall intersect the arterial street within 660 feet of an intersecting arterial or collector street nor within 660 feet of an intersecting local street or highway 2 along an arterial street with speeds less than 50 mph no side street or driveway shall intersect the arterial street within 500 feet of an intersecting arterial or collector street nor within 500 feet of an intersecting local street or driveway 3 along a collector street no side street or driveway shall intersect the collector street within 300 feet of an intersecting arterial street nor within 150 feet of an intersecting local street or driveway 4 along a local street no local street or driveway shall intersect the local street within 75 feet of another intersecting local street except that a driveway for a low density residential development may be reduced to approximately 40 feet 10208 standards for access to arterials and collectors a access to arterials and collectors direct access to an arterial or collector in the form of a private driveway shall only be allowed when no other means of access is available the city or county engineer shall review the subdivision and make a recommendation to the muapb 1 where a proposed commercial or industrial subdivision borders on or contains an existing or proposed limited access arterial or a collector the muapb may require a street system layout which affords separation of local traffic this may be accomplished frontage lots with access control provisions along the rear service areas or frontage roads 2 where a residential subdivision borders on or contains an existing or proposed arterial or collector street the muapb may require that access to the arterial or collector street be limited by any of the following means a when a subdivision abuts an arterial or collector the subdivision of x7 lots shall be laid out so as to back onto the arterial or collector street and front onto a parallel local street or culdesac no access shall be provided directly to any lot from the arterial or collector street pedestrian and bicycle access to the arterial or collector sidewalk system should be accommodated by appropriate use of pedestrian easements  or b a series of culdesacs ushaped streets or short loops shall be provided generally at right angles to a parallel street with their terminal lots backing onto the arterial or collector street and providing no access to the arterial or collector street from such lots pedestrian and bicycle access to the arterial or collector system should be accommodated by appropriate use of pedestrian easements eyebrow culdesacs shall be prohibited unless approved by the muapb  or c a frontage road may be provided and shall be separated from the arterial or collector street by a minimum ten 10 foot wide planting or grass strip and providing access to the arterial street at suitable points 10209 specific street standards a general in order to provide for streets of suitable location width and improvements to accommodate future traffic and afford satisfactory access to emergency and service vehicles  to provide for the safe operation of the street system  and to coordinate streets so as to develop a convenient system that avoids undue hardships to adjoining properties the following standards are hereby required 1 street classification shall be indicated on the functional street classification map 2 rightofway widths right of way widths shall not be less than the following table 1 minimum rightofway widths feet street type city urban service area urban area expressway 120 120 120 arterial 100 100 100 collector 70 80 80 x8 local 50 60 60 culdesac 50 60 60 culdesac turnaround 100 dia 100 dia 100 dia frontage 50 60 60 3 rightofway widths in excess of the minimum standards stated herein shall be required whenever due to topography or other considerations additional width is necessary to provide adequate earth slopes or sight distances as deemed necessary by the muapb rightofway widths may be reduced in accordance with companion easements i 4 other rightofway considerations rightsofway at intersections shall be designed for sight distance considerations for safety reasons and for potential improvements at intersections no less than a thirty 30 foot vision triangle shall be platted as part of the rightofway with any subdivision no fixed aboveground facilities should be located in the sight triangle at the intersection ie utility poles trees etc consideration regarding the width of the rightofway and companion easements should be taken into account when planning the street layout 5 intersection angles streets shall be laid out so as to intersect as nearly as possible at right angles a variation may be approved by the muapb based upon the recommendation of the citycounty engineer the angle of intersection shall not be less than seventyfive 75 degrees 6 multiple intersections intersections involving the junction of more than two 2 streets shall be avoided whenever possible 7 multiple approach intersections intersections involving more than four 4 approaches should be avoided properly designed intersections with an acceptable method to control traffic may be considered 8 horizontal sight distances streets shall be laid out so as to provide for adequate horizontal sight distances on all curves 9 design speed design speed shall be in conformance with applicable sections of aashto a policy on geometric design of highways and streets operating and design speeds at the lower ranges identified in aashto are encouraged 10 street jogs street jogs with centerline offsets of less than onehundredfifty 150 feet shall be prohibited the muapb may require the same standard for culdesacs depending on length of roadway and residential density x9 11 distance between reverse curves a tangent of at least one hundred 100 feet along the street centerline shall be required between horizontal reverse curves on arterial and collector streets 12 curvature when the street centerline deflects more than ten 10 degrees a curve shall be inserted with a radius of footage no less than table 2 minimum curve radii city urban service area urban area arterial 500 500 500 collector 300 300 300 local 150 150 150 a the muapb may upon the advice of the city andor county engineer require an increase in the radius of the applicable curve 13 street grades the grades of streets should not exceed the following percentages table 3 maximum allowable grade street type maximum grade arterial 5% collector 8% local 10% a any grades in excess of the above shall be reviewed by the applicable city or county engineer and a recommendation made to the muapb no street grade shall be less than fivetenths percent 05% unless reviewed and recommended by the city or county engineer 14 traffic calming traffic calming measures are tools to be used in conjunction with the horizontal and vertical design to achieve lower speeds in the local residential street system these measures should be incorporated in the design of the street system recommended measures include but are not limited to entry treatments chokers roundabouts circles textured pavements colored pavement and other geometric features which will tend to reduce speed on a local residential street 10210 standards for alleys a alleys may be approved by the muapb with a subdivision in those instances x10 where alleys are proposed the muapb shall take into account lot and street layout and land uses to be served when alleys are approved with a subdivision the following general standards shall apply 1 alleys shall be platted at a minimum twenty 20 feet in width 2 alleys shall be straight with no alley intersections except as may be approved by the muapb 3 deadend alleys shall be prohibited part 3 standards for blocks 10301 blocks a the lengths widths and shapes of blocks shall be determined with due regard to 1 provision for adequate building sites suitable for the special needs of the type of use contemplated  2 needs for convenient access safety circulation  3 consideration of topography  and 4 zoning requirements as to lot sizes and dimensions b residential block lengths shall not exceed one thousand six hundred 1600 feet c pedestrian easements not less than sixteen 16 feet in width shall be dedicated to the public where deemed beneficial by the muapb to provide for pedestrian access these walkways shall be constructed in a manner approved by the citycounty engineer part 4 standards for lots 10401 a the minimum dimensional requirements for proposed lots shall conform with the applicable zoning regulations of the city andor county that are in effect on the date of final plat submittal or as specified by the county health department b each lot shall provide a buildable area properties reserved or laid out for commercial andor industrial purposes shall be of adequate size to provide for the offstreet service and parking facilities required by the type of use zoning district x11 and development contemplated 1 for multiplefamily commercial or industrial structures andor uses shall provide a buildable area behind the required setbacks which has less than a twenty 20 percent slope in cases where there is no existing slope that is less than twenty 20 percent the lot size should either be increased in area to provide for a buildable area with an existing slope less than twenty 20 percent or a specific grading plan shall be submitted with the preliminary plat which shall be approved by the muapb grading plans shall incorporate provisions which minimize grading removal of vegetation land instability fire or drainage hazards or other public safety hazards such as steep vertical cuts building site offstreet parking lots and driveways must be considered with the grading plan the muapb may require the submittal of building and offstreet parking lot and driveway plans as a condition of approval with the preliminary plat which shall be submitted with the final plat the muapb may deny a plat that does not adequately address the minimization of grading the removal of vegetation or creates public safety hazards such as steep vertical cuts final grading plans shall be submitted with the final plat for subdivisions subject to the provisions of this subsection c where lots are more than double the minimum required area for the zoning district the muapb may require that such lots be arranged so as to allow further subdivision andor the opening of future streets such potential lots shall be in compliance with the zoning regulations of the city andor county and these regulations d through double frontage lots shall be avoided except where essential to provide separation of residential development from a street rightofway eg reverse frontage  or to overcome specific disadvantages of topography and orientation e side lot lines should be at right angles to streets or perpendicular to the tangent except in special cases approved by the muapb such as lot orientation for solar access f be laid out so individual lot drainage shall be coordinated with the existing drainage pattern for the area g the use of flag lots shall be prohibited in all subdivisions except where the muapb determines that topography or other physical conditions on the property necessitate the need for flexibility in the layout of the subdivision the following requirements shall apply to flag lots 1 the pole portion of the lot shall be at least thirty 30 feet in width x12 2 the flag portion of the lot shall comply with the minimum lot requirements for width depth and area for the zoning district in which the lot is located 3 the area of the pole portion of the flag lot shall not be counted towards meeting the minimum lot area requirements of the zoning district in which the flag lot is located 4 if more than one flag lot is proposed to the rear of another lot then the subdivision shall only be considered in conjunction with a planned unit development 5 access to the flag lot shall comply with the requirements of the responsible fire department part 5 standards for solar subdivisions 10501 solar subdivisions subdivisions that are intended to be established to provide for solar access are encouraged to follow the general standards set out below in order to protect solar access and to provide the greatest flexibility in the design and layout of the subdivision the applicable planning department will work with a subdivider to help place restrictions on the plat in order to protect solar access for any subdivision proposal that will be sensitive to the need for solar access a the subdivision should be a planned unit development b open space and landscaping should be located to protect buildings andor solar equipment from shading from other buildings in or adjacent to the subdivision c street orientation should provide proper orientation of buildings or equipment using solar energy d lot orientation should allow for building placements that maximizes use of solar energy e buildings should be located to provide sufficient open yard to the south to ensure solar access on the lot f covenants and restrictions should be provided by the developer to ensure solar siting requirements and solar access protection part 6 standards for easements 10601easements x13 a where necessary easements across lots or centered on lot lines shall be provided for utilities and shall not be less than sixteen 16 feet in width b except where provided in this all poles wires and overhead structures to supply electricity communication services and similar or associated services for all subdivisions within the city of manhattan and the urban service area shall be installed underground within designated utility easements by the subdivider or utility company the provisions of this not apply to any of the following 1 poles used exclusively for street or area lighting or traffic control signals 2 radio television and wireless communication towers and antennas 3 existing poles overhead wires and associated overhead structures when part of a continuous line or services to individual properties from existing overhead lines that are within a subdivision previously approved in conformance with these regulations nothing in this prevent the replacement of existing poles overhead wires and associated overhead structures on lines when necessary for the purpose of maintaining the line or upgrading the capacity 4 subdivisions within the urban area 5 electric distribution or transmission lines with capacities of three thousand 3000 kva or more 6 service terminals transformers regulators meters or other on aboveground facilities normally used with and as a part of an underground distribution system 7 structures on corner lots in streets and alleys and on easements adjacent thereto in cases where electrical and communication wires cross a street or other area where overhead wires are not prohibited may be connected to said overhead wires and are excepted from these regulations 8 existing overhead lines attached to the exterior surface of a building by means of a bracket or other fixture and extending from one 1 location on the building to another location on the same building or to an adjacent building without crossing a property line 9 existing poles overhead wires and associated overhead structures when part of a continuous line or services to individual properties x14 from such existing overhead lines that are within a subdivision previously approved in accordance with existing regulations 10 existing poles overhead wires and associated overhead structures when part of a continuous line or services to individual properties from such existing overhead lines that serve properties adjacent to but not within areas being subdivided 11 any communication line which would otherwise be required by this be underground that uses an overhead pole or structure exempted by this 12 underground installation of wiring or electrical power telephone and cable television shall not be required in flood plains drainage easements major drainage ways or other areas where there is frequently standing water c the subdivider may request a waiver from the requirements of b if physical conditions of the land or economic conditions associated with the nature of the subdivision in question make underground installation infeasible such request shall be accompanied by a report from the responsible public utility stating per linear foot cost differential between the average cost for installation of underground utilities and the estimated cost at the subdivision the muapb shall review the request and shall approve or deny the waiver d the responsible planning department may grant special permission of the requirements of b in cases where temporary electrical power or communication service is reasonably required for emergencies or for building construction purposes or for other temporary purposes to erect construct install or maintain poles wires and other overhead structures for a period not to exceed one hundred twenty 120 days however in the event the purpose for which the temporary exception referred to herein as granted cannot be completed within the period herein provided because of a shortage of material a natural disaster strikes or payment of which the city or county may become liable to another person fire or corporation by reason of any negligence by the utility in the construction maintenance and operation of its utility system within the city or county then upon written request to the responsible planning department the time may be extended an additional temporary period or periods necessary to allow completion of such construction e the subdivider shall make the necessary arrangements for the installation of underground facilities including circuits for streetlights that may be required such arrangements shall be made with each of the companies or persons supplying electrical and communications service therein in accordance with the established charges of such company or person letters from each of such companies or persons indicating that said arrangements have been made shall be x15 submitted to the applicable planning department at the time that application is made for a final plat f whenever any stream or important surface drainage course is located in an area that is being subdivided or is traversed by a water course drainage way channel or stream a drainage easement shall be provided which shall run generally parallel to such water course the subdivider shall provide an adequate drainage easement along each side of the stream for the purpose of future widening deepening sloping improving or protecting the stream  or for drainage parkway or recreational use for areas within the city and the urban service area drainage easements shall be provided as required by the stormwater management master plan swmmp for areas within the urban area drainage easements shall be provided as required by the riley county storm drainage design criteria for platted areas g travel easements may be allowed in accordance with h pedestrian easements may be required in accordance with a2c1 in those specific cases where residential subdivisions abut an arterial or collector street pedestrian access from the local street to the arterial or collector street shall be provided every 600 feet where deemed appropriate commercial and industrial subdivisions shall provide pedestrian access to arterial and collector streets as needed i companion easements utility and other service easements may be placed along both sides of the street rightofway at widths determined by the affected utilities or services specific criteria for the application of companion easements include 1 location companion easements are parallel to the rightofway with uniform widths unless specified differently by the responsible engineer 2 use companion easements can be used for the placement of sidewalks trees utilities street lights street signs etc 3 applicability the use of companion easements shall be determined at the platting stage either in the preliminary plat or in a replat for residential subdivisions j avigation easements and other restrictions land located within the vicinity of established flight paths and noise impact areas of publicowned or controlled airports as determined by the muapb shall be required to grant a permanent avigation easement to the public as may be necessary to allow aircraft to operate within the navigable airspace as defined by the federal aviation act of 195 as amended consistent with faa regulations the muapb may disapprove a plat or portion thereof which could create a hazardous situation for air traffic and x16 the general public resulting from development and construction of a project k conservation easements may be allowed in accordance with l fire department access easement the muapb upon the recommendation of the applicable fire department may require an easement for access by fire fighting apparatus in the following circumstances 1 where appropriate street projections are not provided to urbanwildland interface areas adjacent to developing areas  or 2 where a culdesac greater than six hundred 600 feet in length has been permitted  or 3 where a subdivision has been allowed with only one access part 7 standards for storm drainage 10701 storm drainage and required improvements a for all plats proposed within the city and urban service area the subdivider shall submit a storm drainage plan that conforms with the requirements and criteria of the stormwater management master plan swmmp unless such submittal is waived by the responsible city engineer pursuant to contents and submission requirements for plats and plans b1 and b8 for all plats proposed within the urban area the subdivider shall submit a storm drainage plan that conforms with the riley county storm drainage design criteria for platted areas unless such submittal is waived by the responsible county engineer pursuant to contents and submission requirements for plats and plans b1 and b8 the storm drainage plan shall contain such information as may be required by the city or county engineer and shall be reviewed and approved by the city or county engineer b for subdivisions proposed within the city or the urban service area all storm drainage improvements shall be designed according to the requirements and criteria of the swmmp for subdivisions proposed within the urban area all storm drainage improvements shall be designed according to the requirements and criteria of the riley county storm drainage design criteria for platted areas part 8 standards for community assets 10801 community assets all subdivisions shall be sensitive to the protection and preservation of existing site features within the proposed subdivision whether natural or manmade such that the protection or preservation of the site feature would add x17 value to the development or to the community as a whole such site features would include historic sites or structures critical habitats of wildlife or rare and unusual plants wetlands drainage courses large andor valuable trees or similar irreplaceable assets that are listed on a local state or federal listing shall be preserved in the design of the subdivision to the maximum extent possible conservation easements or other similar means must be used to preserve community assets part 9 standards for planned unit developments pud 10901 a request for a pud classification pursuant to the zoning regulations shall also be considered to be an application for a preliminary plat pursuant to these regulations subsequent to approval of a pud the subdividerapplicant shall submit a final plat to the muapb for approval such final plat shall be approved if it conforms to the approved pud in reviewing a requested pud both the muapb and the applicable governing body shall require compliance with these regulations unless they make a specific finding that a variation from these regulations is appropriate under the circumstances and also set forth their reasons for such variation neither the muapb nor the applicable governing body shall be required to approve a pud simply because it complies with these regulations the standards for approval of puds shall be governed by the applicable zoning regulations part 10 standards for sidewalks 101001 sidewalks sidewalks shall be required as part of the street improvements in the city and the urban service areas in the following manners a all sidewalks shall be constructed to standards set by the responsible engineering department the muapb may require greater widths where pedestrian volumes dictate b a median strip of grassed or landscaped area at least six 6 feet wide should separate all sidewalks from adjacent curbs c sidewalks shall be located within the dedicated nonpavement street rightofway or within the companion easements d sidewalks shall be required on both sides of all arterial and collector streets and one side of all local streets e when unique topographic or other unique site conditions dictate the subdivider may submit an alternative pedestrian and bicycle circulation system to the muapb for consideration as a variation of the alternative circulation system must be consistent with the general requirements for adequate and functional pedestrian and bicycle circulation and connectivity to adjacent areas and shall demonstrate a well documented need for an alternative approach x18 f sidewalks shall conform to accessibility standards part 11 standards for water and sewer facilities 101101 water and sewer facilities a all subdivisions located either within the city limits or in areas to be annexed by the city shall have water and sanitary sewer systems designed to the standards of the city engineering and fire departments b all subdivisions within the urban service areas but not on city services shall design the water and sanitary sewer systems to comply with city engineering standards and shall also be designed in a manner so as to be compatible with city systems when such systems are extended to these subdivisions installation of such improvements shall be inspected and approved by the city engineering department c all subdivisions within the urban area shall design their water and sanitary sewer systems in accordance with county engineering and health department standards part 12 standards for bench marks corners monuments and other markers 101201 bench marks corners monuments and other markers a bench marks 1 all elevations shown on plats shall be based on national geodetic survey ngs datum 2 the permanent bench mark location and description that is used to extend datum to the project shall be noted on the preliminary plat and final plat b monuments 1 monuments at the main controlling corners of each unit of a subdivision shall consist of an iron bar at least onehalf 12 inch in diameter three 3 feet long and be encased in concrete variations to the three 3 foot length may be allowed based on subsurface conditions 2 all lot corners and control points for horizontal curves within the subdivision shall be marked with an iron bar at least onehalf 12 inch in diameter at least two 2 feet long x19 3 identification plaques indicating lot numbers shall be placed at each lot corner along the front of the lot and the appropriate sign posts shall be no less than four 4 feet above ground c us government corners whenever a survey originates from a united states public land survey corner or any related accessory the land surveyor shall file a copy of the completed survey and references to the corner or accessory with the department of archives kansas state historical society and with the county surveyor such survey shall be filed within thirty 30 days of the date the references are made 1 any altered removed damaged or destroyed corner shall be restored 2 whenever such a corner or any related accessory is restored reestablished or replaced due to construction activities a restoration report shall be filed with the department of archives kansas state historical society as specified in kansas statutes d existing markers at any time during construction of the subdivision if a stone marker should be found the developer shall place an iron disc next to the stone to facilitate the location of the stone in the future x20 article xi construction and definitions part 1 construction 11101 unless a contrary intention clearly appears the following words and phrases shall have for the purpose of these regulations the meanings given in the following clauses any word or term not defined herein shall be used in a meaning of standard usage a words used in the present tense shall include the future b the singular shall include the plural c the word shall is mandatory d the word may is permissive e the phrase used for shall include the phrases arranged for designed for maintained for and occupied for f unless otherwise specified all distances shall be measured horizontally g the acronym muapb shall mean the manhattan urban area planning board h the word city shall mean the city of manhattan kansas i the word county shall mean the county of riley kansas j whenever reference is made to either the city or county the applicable one based on conditions set out in b shall apply k the word township shall mean any township as they may be affected by these regulations l the word ordinance shall include the words resolution or regulations part 2 definitions 11201 the following definitions shall be used in the construction and interpretation of these regulations aashto american association of state and highway transportation officials xi1 alley a dedicated public rightofway other than a street that affords a secondary means of access to abutting property allweather road a road of any surface material which would normally allow the passage of emergency service vehicles used to respond to the location within the city or county applicant a subdivider submitting an application for a subdivision application an application and all accompanying documentation required by these regulations for approval of a plat area the size of a tract of land usually described in terms of square feet or acres benefit district an area deemed by the governing body to be benefited by an improvement and subject to special assessment for all or a portion of the cost of the improvement ie streets water sewage bicycle lane a portion of the roadway which has been designated by signs striping andor pavement markings for the sole use of bicyclists bicycle route a roadway designated to provide continuity and connectivity with other elements of a bikeway system the bike route is usually distinguished only by signing block a unit of land enclosed by streets or by a combination of streets railroad rightsofway watercourses or any other barrier to the continuity of development in cases where the platting is incomplete or disconnected the city or county engineer shall determine the outline of the block boundary line adjustment the relocation of a common boundary line between two 2 platted lots by mutual agreement of the owners of the two 2 lots by following the procedure in of these regulations buildable area the area of a lot remaining after all setbacks and easements of the zoning regulations have been deducted the buildable area shall be feasible and practical for the intended uses and structures of the zoning district in which the lot is located building any covered structure built for the support shelter or enclosure of persons animals chattels or movable property of any kind and which is permanently affixed to the land xi2 building setback line a dashed line on the preliminary and final plat which designates the distance between the front lot line and the principal building on the lot or the distance between a travel easement and the principal building on the lot capital improvements program cip the process of budgeting for largescale public expenditures which are expected to have a relatively long life the cip usually involves an investment in land buildings roads and other public works which produce public services or benefits the citys cip also includes expenditures for large longlasting pieces of equipment and studies or surveys that may be done by consultants comprehensive plan the plan as adopted pursuant to ksa 12747 or as may be amended contiguous next to abutting or touching and having a boundary or portion thereof which is the same boundary covenant an agreement or promise to do or not to do a particular thing  to enter into a formal agreement binding oneself in contract which is either expressed or implied restrictive covenants private agreements between a prior landowner and a buyer or transferee which restrict the use of the land in some way for example restrictive covenants used in many subdivisions may limit the land to residential use with buildings of a certain minimum size and setback restrictive covenants are generally said to run with the land so that all future owners are bound by them deed restriction a covenant or condition entered in the public record to limit the nature or intensity of land or realty dedication a conveyance of land by a private owner in the nature of a gift grant or as required by regulation and an acceptance of that land by or on behalf of the public example street rightofway utility easement detention basin pond a storage facility for the temporary storage of storm water runoff usually the basins are planted with grass and may be used for open space or recreation in periods of dry weather developer the legal owner or owners of a lot or any land included in a proposed development or the holder of an option or contract to purchase or any person having the authority to submit an application for approval of a subdivision under these regulations see subdivider xi3 development any manmade change to improved or unimproved real estate including but not limited to buildings or other structures mining dredging filling grading paving excavation or drilling operations drainage the removal of surface water or groundwater from land by drains grading or other means which include runoff controls to minimize erosion and sedimentation during and after construction or development the means for preserving the water supply and the prevention or alleviation of flooding drainage area that area in which all of the surface runoff resulting from precipitation is concentrated into a particular stream easement a grant of one or more of the property rights by the property owner to andor for the use by the public a corporation or another person or entity the property owner retains title of the land under easement avigation an air rights easement which protects air lanes flight paths and navigable airspace around airports companion an easement reducing the normal width of a public rightofway on local streets by providing utility and other service easements along both sides of the street rightofway drainage an easement required for the installation of storm water sewers or drainage ditches detention or retention basins andor required for the preservation or maintenance of a natural stream or water course or other drainage facility pedestrian an easement for providing pedestrian access temporary an easement utilized for construction purposes or to give access for a limited specified period of time travel an easement created to serve by providing access to pedestrians and vehicles in the same manner as a local street utility an easement within which the common service delivery lines electric telephone water sanitary sewer etc are located fire apparatus access road an allweather road used as a secondary means of access to a subdivision which may have only one entrance or at the end of a dead end culdesac or as may be determined by the muapb as recommended by the city or county fire department which has a minimum width of twenty 20 feet and a clear height of thirteen 13 feet six 6 inches and designed to accommodate the loads and turning radii for fire apparatus and which is gradient negotiable by the fire apparatus xi4 normally used at that location within the city or county fire department access road an all weather road connecting to an urban wildland interface with a minimum width of twelve 12 feet and a minimum unobstructed height of thirteen 13 feet six 6 inches flood plain any land area susceptible to being inundated by water from any source see flooding base flood a flood having a one percent 1% chance of being equaled or exceeded in any given year base flood elevation the elevation shown on the flood insurance rate map firm which is representative of the base flood flood insurance study the official report provided in which the federal emergency management agency fema has provided flood profiles as well as the flood boundary floodway map and the surface elevation of the base flood flood insurance rate map firm the official map on which fema has delineated both the areas of special flood hazards and the risk premium zones applicable to the community flood plain regulations the official flood plain regulations as adopted by the city or county floodway the channel of a river or other watercourse and adjacent land areas that must be reserved in order to discharge the base flood without cumulatively increasing the water surface elevation more than one 1 foot floodway fringe that portion of the flood plain outside of the floodway flooding a general and temporary condition of partial or complete inundation of normally dry land areas from the overflow of waters normally confined between the banks of a stream or other water course  or the unusual and rapid accumulation of runoff of surface waters from any source frontage the length of a front line or lines ie that side of a lot abutting on a street governing body the elected city commission of manhattan or the board of commissioners of riley county when reference is made to the governing body it shall apply to the appropriate body having jurisdiction over the land being developed xi5 guarantee a form of security including a cash deposit surety bond collateral property or instrument of credit in an amount and form satisfactory to the responsible engineer all guarantees shall be approved by the responsible governing body wherever a bond is required by these regulations improvements street pavement or resurfacing curbs gutters sidewalks waterlines sewer lines storm drains street lights street signs flood control and drainage facilities utility lines linear trails landscaping and other related matters normally associated with the development of raw land into building sites linear trail a pedestrianbicycle way that may be located within or away from a public rightofway and is an alternate path and usually part of a trail system lot a designated parcel plot tract or area of land established by a subdivision plat to be used developed or built upon as a unit a lot shall not have less than the minimum area and width required by the zoning regulations for the specified zoning district corner a lot abutting upon two or more streets at their intersection a lot abutting on a curved street or streets shall be considered a corner lot if straight lines drawn from the foremost points of the side lot lines to the foremost point of the lot meet at an interior angle less than 135 degrees depth the distance between the midpoint of the front lot line and the midpoint of the rear lot line flag shall mean a lot that is characterized by a strip of land not less than 30 feet in width which provides access to the main portion of the lot referred to as the flag the strip of land shall be referred to as the pole of the flag lot interior a lot whose side lot lines do not abut upon any street lines the lines bounding a lot so defined herein minimum area of the area of a lot exclusive of any portion of the rightofway of any public or private street of record a lot which is part of a subdivision the plat of which has been recorded in the office of the register of deeds of riley or pottawatomie county or a parcel of land the deed to which was recorded prior to adoption of these regulations xi6 reverse frontage a lot extending between and having frontage on an arterial street and a local street with vehicular access solely from the latter split the subdividing of a platted lot into two 2 or more lots by obtaining the approval of the responsible planning department pursuant to of these regulations and without any necessity to follow the normal procedure for the subdivision of land through an interior lot which fronts upon two parallel streets or which fronts upon two streets which do not intersect at the boundaries of such a lot also called a double frontage lot width the distance between the side lot lines of a lot measured at right angles to the line establishing the lot depth at the established building setback line manhattan urban area urban area urban service area and the city manhattan urban area the area of jurisdiction for these regulations as established in the interlocal agreement or as it may be amended it is a combination of the incorporated area the city portions of the county that could be provided services urban service area and those other county areas generally adjacent to the city or the urban service area urban area urban area the urban area is an area located adjacent to the city or between the urban service area and manhattan urban area boundary which is not envisioned or identified in the comprehensive plan to be developed to an urban scale city utilities are not recommended to be extended into the urban area urban service area usa those portions of the county within the manhattan urban area that can be served by existing city public facilities and utilities or extension of these facilities the urban service area is identified as the citys growth boundary for future urban density development comprehensive plan city the incorporated portion of the city within the manhattan urban area manhattan urban area planning board the muapb as established by the interlocal agreement between the city and county monument permanent concrete or iron markers used to establish all lines of the plat of a subdivision including all lot corners boundary line corners and points of change in street alignment xi7 net density the number of dwelling units permitted by the zoning district in which the subdivision is or will be located net density is calculated by dividing the number of dwelling units by the net development area within the subdivision net development area is determined by subtracting areas set aside for streets churches schools or other nonresidential uses from the gross acreage within the subdivision land set aside for common open space or recreational use is included in net development area for the purpose of determining the number of dwelling units permitted in residential planned unit developments the number of dwelling units is determined by dividing the net development area by the minimum lot area per family required by the district or districts in which the site is located permit building a certificate issued by the responsible city or county department or an official designee to allow construction of a specific type of structure permit occupancy a permit issued by the responsible city or county department or an official designee which certifies that such land use structure or building is fit for human occupancy and complies with all the provisions of the zoning regulations and other applicable city or county codes ordinances rules and regulations person the word person shall include individuals firms corporations associations partnerships government bodies and agencies and all other legal entities planned unit development pud a zoning district classification that combines subdivision zoning site planning and design processes to accommodate a flexible and unified pattern of development which can more easily address unique constraints and conditions on a specific tract of land plat a map as a formal document representing a tract of land showing the boundaries and location of individual properties and streets  a map and a legal description of a subdivision or a site plan concurrent plat the simultaneous submission of a preliminary plat and a final plat consisting of five 5 or fewer lots concept plat a preliminary presentation of a future land development contiguous to a proposed subdivision of sufficient accuracy to be used for discussion in order to coordinate street utility drainage park and other land development issues xi8 final plat the final map of all or a phased portion of a subdivision which is submitted to the muapb for final approval and to the governing body for acceptance of dedications preliminary plat a preliminary map indicating the proposed layout of the subdivision which is submitted to the muapb for consideration and approval replat a change redrafting andor resubmission of a previously approved preliminary andor final plat changes may include lot lines easements rightsofway design concepts or adherence to changes in local ordinances andor regulations that may control subdivisions short form plat a plat prepared on linen ledger 100% cotton rag paper for concurrent plats within the urban area sketch plat a rough sketch map of a proposed subdivision or site plan that is of sufficient accuracy to be used for the purpose of discussion clarification and consensus poles wires and overhead structures includes but is not limited to poles towers supports wires conductors guys stubs platforms crossarms braces line transformers insulators cutouts switches communication circuits appliances attachments and appurtenances located above ground upon along across or over streets alleys and easements and used in supplying electric communication or similar or related service public facilities and services any and all public improvements the need for which is directly or indirectly generated by the subdivision reservation willingness by a private owner to withhold specific real estate from further development pending acquisition by a public entity reserve strip a strip of land across the end of or along the edge of a street or alley or lot for the purposes of controlling access which is reserved or held until future street extension or widening resubdivision any change to a previously approved or recorded subdivision plat see replat retention basin a pond pool or basin used for the permanent storage of water runoff rightofway row a strip of land acquired by reservation dedication or condemnation and intended for use as a public way the row normally incorporates the roadway curbs parking strips sidewalks lighting and drainage xi9 facilities other utilities and may include special features required by topography such as grade separation landscape areas viaducts or bridges rightofway width the shortest distance between the property lines abutting both sides of a street rightofway roundabout a traffic control device that provides for the safe and efficient movement of traffic intersection screening a method of visually shielding or obscuring one abutting or nearby structure or use from another by decorative fencing densely planted evergreen vegetation earthen mounds or berms walls or a combination of these to reduce noise offensive views or heat secretary of the muapb the responsible staff liaison of either the city or county septic disposal system an onsite underground sewage system which incorporates pipes tanks and a leach field for the collection and disposal of domestic commercial or industrial wastes from a single source setback the distance between the front lot line and the principal building on the lot sidewalk a paved area generally parallel to and usually separated from the street and used as a pedestrian walkway sight distance the length of street measured along the centerline which is continuously visible from any point three 3 feet above the centerline slope the number of feet of vertical fall or rise per one hundred 100 feet of horizontal distance ie percent grade vertical change in feet percent slope   horizontal change in feet x 100 street a public thoroughfare and vehicular way which affords principal means of access to property abutting thereon whether named or designated as a street highway parkway road avenue roadway boulevard lane or however otherwise designated expressway an access controlled multilane arterial highway which may be separated by a median and intended for with or without grade separation arterial a street providing for movement to concentrated xi10 areas of activity with or without a median divider and providing access to abutting property subject to necessary control of entrances exits and curb cuts and protected by stop signs or signals at cross streets and highways collector a street providing for traffic movement between arterials and local streets and providing for access to abutting property traffic is controlled to some extent at cross streets local street a street used primarily for access to abutting properties and serving the local needs of a neighborhood culdesac a local street having only one open end and being permanently terminated at the other end by a vehicular turnaround frontage road or marginal access road a street running parallel to an expressway or arterial and serving abutting properties halfstreet a street bordering one or more property lines of a tract of land in which the subdivider has dedicated half of the ultimate street rightofway width subdivider the word subdivider shall also mean owner applicant developer or a duly authorized agent of the owner of record of the land intended for subdivision subdivision the division of a lot tract or parcel of land into two or more lots tracts parcels of land for sale development lease or other similar purpose such division may also include as an integral part of such division the dedicating vacating or reserving of streets alleys parks and easements intended for public use substantial compliance the demonstrated adherence to conditions established by the muapb or governing body consistent with the intent and standards of these regulations township a rural government division within the county the term originated from the congressional township  a geographical area concept of usually 35 square miles which was used to survey america the manhattan urban area is located within the townships of manhattan ogden and wildcat traffic circle a traffic control method used only in residential areas to provide traffic calming to the street system a traffic circle is generally used as a retrofit measure urbanwildland interface an area where a subdivision or development and contiguous land meet whether at a clearly or undefined xi11 boundary the interface area is where combustible fuels vegetative or other combustible materials exist and which have the potential to contribute to the intensity and spread of wildfire variation a deviation from the subdivision layout standards of these regulations subject to the requirements set forth in these regulations and as approved by the muapb vicinity map a drawing located on the preliminary and final plat which illustrates the relationship of the proposed subdivision to the established street systems other nearby developments or landmarkscommunity facilities for the purpose of locating and orienting the area under consideration water bodies any natural or artificial collection of water whether permanent or temporary water course any natural or artificial stream river creek ditch channel canal conduit culvert drain waterway gully ravine or wash in which water flow is in a definite direction or course water can flow either continuously or intermittently and has a definite channel bed and banks and includes any area adjacent thereto subject to inundation by reason of overflow or floodwater wildfire an unplanned and uncontrolled fire spreading or other combustible materials and possibly involving structures zoning regulations the official zoning regulations of the city or the county as adopted or as may be amended xi12
